5#ifndef V8_SANDBOX_EXTERNAL_ENTITY_TABLE_H_
6#define V8_SANDBOX_EXTERNAL_ENTITY_TABLE_H_
7
8#include <set>
9
10#include "include/v8-platform.h"
11#include "include/v8config.h"
12#include "src/base/atomicops.h"
13#include "src/base/memory.h"
14#include "src/base/platform/mutex.h"
15#include "src/common/globals.h"
16
17#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
18
19namespace v8 {
20namespace internal {
21
22class Isolate;
23
51template <typename Entry, size_t size>
52class V8_EXPORT_PRIVATE ExternalEntityTable {
53 protected:
54 static constexpr int kEntrySize = sizeof(Entry);
55 static constexpr size_t kReservationSize = size;
56 static constexpr size_t kMaxCapacity = kReservationSize / kEntrySize;
57
58 // For managing the table's backing memory, the table is partitioned into
59 // segments of this size. Segments can then be allocated and freed using the
60 // AllocateTableSegment() and FreeTableSegment() routines.
61 static constexpr size_t kSegmentSize = 64 * KB;
62 static constexpr size_t kEntriesPerSegment = kSegmentSize / kEntrySize;
63
64 // Struct representing a segment of the table.
65 struct Segment {
66 public:
67 // Initialize a segment given its number.
68 explicit Segment(uint32_t number) : number_(number) {}
69
70 // Returns the segment starting at the specified offset from the base of the
71 // table.
72 static Segment At(uint32_t offset);
73
74 // Returns the segment containing the entry at the given index.
75 static Segment Containing(uint32_t entry_index);
76
77 // The segments of a table are numbered sequentially. This method returns
78 // the number of this segment.
79 uint32_t number() const { return number_; }
80
81 // Returns the offset of this segment from the table base.
82 uint32_t offset() const { return number_ * kSegmentSize; }
83
84 // Returns the index of the first entry in this segment.
85 uint32_t first_entry() const { return number_ * kEntriesPerSegment; }
86
87 // Return the index of the last entry in this segment.
88 uint32_t last_entry() const {
89 return first_entry() + kEntriesPerSegment - 1;
90 }
91
92 // Segments are ordered by their id/offset.
93 bool operator<(const Segment& other) const {
94 return number_ < other.number_;
95 }
96
97 private:
98 // A segment is identified by its number, which is its offset from the base
99 // of the table divided by the segment size.
100 const uint32_t number_;
101 };
102
103 // Struct representing the head of the freelist.
104 //
105 // An external entity table uses simple, singly-linked lists to manage free
106 // entries. Each entry on the freelist contains the 32-bit index of the next
107 // entry. The last entry points to zero.
108 struct FreelistHead {
109 constexpr FreelistHead() : next_(0), length_(0) {}
110 constexpr FreelistHead(uint32_t next, uint32_t length)
111 : next_(next), length_(length) {}
112
113 // Returns the index of the next entry on the freelist.
114 // If the freelist is empty, this returns zero.
115 uint32_t next() const { return next_; }
116
117 // Returns the total length of the freelist.
118 uint32_t length() const { return length_; }
119
120 bool is_empty() const { return length_ == 0; }
121
122 private:
123 uint32_t next_;
124 uint32_t length_;
125 };
126
127 // We expect the FreelistHead struct to fit into a single atomic word.
128 // Otherwise, access to it would be slow.
129 static_assert(std::atomic<FreelistHead>::is_always_lock_free);
130
131 // A collection of segments in an external entity table.
132 //
133 // For the purpose of memory management, a table is partitioned into segments
134 // of a fixed size (e.g. 64kb). A Space is a collection of segments that all
135 // share the same freelist. As such, entry allocation and freeing (e.g.
136 // through garbage collection) all happen on the level of spaces.
137 //
138 // Spaces allow implementing features such as:
139 // * Young generation GC support (a separate space is used for all entries
140 // belonging to the young generation)
141 // * Having double-width entries in a table (a dedicated space is used that
142 // contains only double-width entries)
143 // * Sharing one table between multiple isolates that perform GC independently
144 // (each Isolate owns one space)
145 struct Space {
146 public:
147 Space() = default;
148 Space(const Space&) = delete;
149 Space& operator=(const Space&) = delete;
150 ~Space();
151
152 // Determines the number of entries currently on the freelist.
153 // As entries can be allocated from other threads, the freelist size may
154 // have changed by the time this method returns. As such, the returned
155 // value should only be treated as an approximation.
156 uint32_t freelist_length() const;
157
158 // Returns the current number of segments currently associated with this
159 // space.
160 // The caller must lock the mutex.
161 uint32_t num_segments();
162
163 // Returns whether this space is currently empty.
164 // The caller must lock the mutex.
165 bool is_empty() { return num_segments() == 0; }
166
167 // Returns the current capacity of this space.
168 // The capacity of a space is the total number of entries it can contain.
169 // The caller must lock the mutex.
170 uint32_t capacity() { return num_segments() * kEntriesPerSegment; }
171
172 // Returns true if this space contains the entry with the given index.
173 bool Contains(uint32_t index);
174
175 // Whether this space is attached to a table's internal read-only segment.
176 bool is_internal_read_only_space() const {
177 return is_internal_read_only_space_;
178 }
179
180#ifdef DEBUG
181 // Check whether this space belongs to the given external entity table.
182 bool BelongsTo(const void* table) const { return owning_table_ == table; }
183#endif // DEBUG
184
185 protected:
186 friend class ExternalEntityTable<Entry, size>;
187
188#ifdef DEBUG
189 // In debug builds we keep track of which table a space belongs to to be
190 // able to insert additional DCHECKs that verify that spaces are always used
191 // with the correct table.
192 std::atomic<void*> owning_table_ = nullptr;
193#endif
194
195 // The freelist used by this space.
196 // This contains both the index of the first entry in the freelist and the
197 // total length of the freelist as both values need to be updated together
198 // in a single atomic operation to stay consistent in the case of concurrent
199 // entry allocations.
200 std::atomic<FreelistHead> freelist_head_ = FreelistHead();
201
202 // The collection of segments belonging to this space.
203 std::set<Segment> segments_;
204
205 // Whether this is the internal RO space, which has special semantics:
206 // - read-only page permissions after initialization,
207 // - the space is not swept since slots are live by definition,
208 // - contains exactly one segment, located at offset 0, and
209 // - the segment's lifecycle is managed by `owning_table_`.
210 bool is_internal_read_only_space_ = false;
211
212 // Mutex guarding access to the segments_ set.
213 base::Mutex mutex_;
214 };
215
216 // A Space that supports black allocations.
217 struct SpaceWithBlackAllocationSupport : public Space {
218 bool allocate_black() { return allocate_black_; }
219 void set_allocate_black(bool allocate_black) {
220 allocate_black_ = allocate_black;
221 }
222
223 private:
224 bool allocate_black_ = false;
225 };
226
227 ExternalEntityTable() = default;
228 ExternalEntityTable(const ExternalEntityTable&) = delete;
229 ExternalEntityTable& operator=(const ExternalEntityTable&) = delete;
230
231 // Access the entry at the specified index.
232 Entry& at(uint32_t index);
233 const Entry& at(uint32_t index) const;
234
235 // Returns true if this table has been initialized.
236 bool is_initialized() const;
237
238 // Returns the base address of this table.
239 Address base() const;
240
241 // Allocates a new entry in the given space and return its index.
242 //
243 // If there are no free entries, then this will extend the space by
244 // allocating a new segment.
245 // This method is atomic and can be called from background threads.
246 uint32_t AllocateEntry(Space* space);
247
248 // Attempts to allocate an entry in the given space below the specified index.
249 //
250 // If there are no free entries at a lower index, this method will fail and
251 // return zero. This method will therefore never allocate a new segment.
252 // This method is atomic and can be called from background threads.
253 uint32_t AllocateEntryBelow(Space* space, uint32_t threshold_index);
254
255 // Try to allocate the first entry of the freelist.
256 //
257 // This method is mostly a wrapper around an atomic compare-and-swap which
258 // replaces the current freelist head with the next entry in the freelist,
259 // thereby allocating the entry at the start of the freelist.
260 bool TryAllocateEntryFromFreelist(Space* space, FreelistHead freelist);
261
262 // Allocate a new segment and add it to the given space.
263 //
264 // This should only be called when the freelist of the space is currently
265 // empty. It will then refill the freelist with all entries in the newly
266 // allocated segment.
267 FreelistHead Extend(Space* space);
268
269 // Sweeps the given space.
270 //
271 // This will free all unmarked entries to the freelist and unmark all live
272 // entries. The table is swept top-to-bottom so that the freelist ends up
273 // sorted. During sweeping, new entries must not be allocated.
274 //
275 // This is a generic implementation of table sweeping and requires that the
276 // Entry type implements the following additional methods:
277 // - bool IsMarked()
278 // - void Unmark()
279 //
280 // Returns the number of live entries after sweeping.
281 uint32_t GenericSweep(Space* space);
282
283 // Allocate a new segment in this table.
284 //
285 // The memory of the newly allocated segment is guaranteed to be
286 // zero-initialized.
287 Segment AllocateTableSegment();
288
289 // Free the specified segment of this table.
290 //
291 // The memory of this segment will afterwards be inaccessible.
292 void FreeTableSegment(Segment segment);
293
294 // Iterate over all entries in the given space.
295 //
296 // The callback function will be invoked for every entry and be passed the
297 // index of that entry as argument.
298 template <typename Callback>
299 void IterateEntriesIn(Space* space, Callback callback);
300
301 // Marker value for the freelist_head_ member to indicate that entry
302 // allocation is currently forbidden, for example because the table is being
303 // swept as part of a mark+sweep garbage collection. This value should never
304 // occur as freelist_head_ value during normal operations and should be easy
305 // to recognize.
306 static constexpr FreelistHead kEntryAllocationIsForbiddenMarker =
307 FreelistHead(-1, -1);
308
309 public:
310 // Initializes the table by reserving the backing memory, allocating an
311 // initial segment, and populating the freelist.
312 void Initialize();
313
314 // Deallocates all memory associated with this table.
315 void TearDown();
316
317 // Initializes the given space for use with this table.
318 void InitializeSpace(Space* space);
319
320 // Deallocates all segments owned by the given space.
321 void TearDownSpace(Space* space);
322
323 // Attaches/detaches the given space to the internal read-only segment. Note
324 // the lifetime of the underlying segment itself is managed by the table.
325 void AttachSpaceToReadOnlySegment(Space* space);
326 void DetachSpaceFromReadOnlySegment(Space* space);
327
328 // Use this scope to temporarily unseal the read-only segment (i.e. change
329 // permissions to RW).
330 class UnsealReadOnlySegmentScope final {
331 public:
332 explicit UnsealReadOnlySegmentScope(ExternalEntityTable<Entry, size>* table)
333 : table_(table) {
334 table_->UnsealReadOnlySegment();
335 }
336
337 ~UnsealReadOnlySegmentScope() { table_->SealReadOnlySegment(); }
338
339 private:
340 ExternalEntityTable<Entry, size>* const table_;
341 };
342
343 private:
344 // Required for Isolate::CheckIsolateLayout().
345 friend class Isolate;
346
347 static constexpr uint32_t kInternalReadOnlySegmentOffset = 0;
348 static constexpr uint32_t kInternalNullEntryIndex = 0;
349
350 // Helpers to toggle the first segment's permissions between kRead (sealed)
351 // and kReadWrite (unsealed).
352 void UnsealReadOnlySegment();
353 void SealReadOnlySegment();
354
355 // Extends the given space with the given segment.
356 FreelistHead Extend(Space* space, Segment segment);
357
358 // The pointer to the base of the virtual address space backing this table.
359 // All entry accesses happen through this pointer.
360 // It is equivalent to |vas_->base()| and is effectively const after
361 // initialization since the backing memory is never reallocated.
362 Entry* base_ = nullptr;
363
364 // The virtual address space backing this table.
365 // This is used to manage the underlying OS pages, in particular to allocate
366 // and free the segments that make up the table.
367 VirtualAddressSpace* vas_ = nullptr;
368};
369
370} // namespace internal
371} // namespace v8
372
373#endif // V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
374
375#endif // V8_SANDBOX_EXTERNAL_ENTITY_TABLE_H_
